Package space.sunqian.fs.io

Interface ByteProcessor

public interface ByteProcessor
This interface represents a processor to process byte data, from the specified data source, through zero or more intermediate operations, finally produces a result or side effect, and the result will be written into a destination (if any). The following example shows a typical processing: 

 ByteProcessor.from(input)
     .readBlockSize(1024)
     .readLimit(1024 * 8)
     .transformer(transformer)
     .processTo(output);

There are types of methods in this interface:

  • Setting methods: set the processing arguments to the current processor before a terminal method is invoked;
  • Terminal methods: produce the processing result or side effect. Once a terminal method is invoked, the current processor will be invalid, any further operations of the current processor will be undefined;
The processor is lazy, operations on the source data are only performed when a terminal method is invoked, and the source data are consumed only as needed. Positions of the source and destination will increment by the actual read and write number.

      @Nonnull @Nonnull ByteProcessor readLimit(long readLimit) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Sets the maximum number of bytes to read from the data source.

      This is an optional setting method.

      Parameters:

      Returns:
      this
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the limit is negative

    • readBlockSize

      @Nonnull @Nonnull ByteProcessor readBlockSize(int readBlockSize) throws IllegalArgumentException
      Sets the number of bytes for each read operation from the data source. The default is IOKit.bufferSize(). This setting is typically used for block-based processing.

      This is an optional setting method.

      Parameters:
      readBlockSize - the number of bytes for each read operation from the data source, must > 0
      Returns:
      this
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the block size is non-positive

    • transformer

      @Nonnull @Nonnull ByteProcessor transformer(@Nonnull @Nonnull ByteTransformer transformer)
      Adds the given transformer to this processor as the last transformer.

      When the processing starts and there is at least one transformer, the processor reads a block of data from the data source, then passes the data block to the first transformer, then passes the result of the first transformer to the next transformer, and so on. If any transformer returns null, the current transformation chain will break. The last result of the last transformer, which serves as the final result, will be written to the destination if the final result is not empty. The processor continues this read-transform loop, until it reaches the end of the data source, or read number reaches the limit value set by readLimit(long). The logic is as follows: 

      
 while (true) {
     ByteSegment block = readNextBlock(blockSize, readLimit);
     ByteBuffer data = block.data();
     boolean end = block.end();
     for (ByteTransformer transformer : transformers) {
         if (data == null) {
             break;
         }
         data = transformer.transform(data, end);
     }
     if (notEmpty(data)) {
         writeTo(data);
     }
     if (end) {
         break;
     }
 }

      The block size is typically determined by readBlockSize(int). And the data blocks are typically read by ByteReader.read(int), thus, their content may be shared with the data source. Changes to the data blocks may be reflected in the data source.

      Normally, for the data block passed to the transformer, the unconsumed portion is ignored by the processor and will not be prepended to the next passed block. Use ByteTransformer.withBuffered(ByteTransformer) if it is needed.

      This is an optional setting method. ByteProcessor also provides some specific transformer wrappers such as: ByteTransformer.withFixedSize(ByteTransformer, int) and ByteTransformer.withMultipleSize(ByteTransformer, int).

      Parameters:
      transformer - the given transformer
      Returns:
      this

    • process

      default long process() throws IORuntimeException
      Starts data processing and returns the actual number of bytes read. If reaches the end of the data source and no data is read, returns -1.

      The position of the data source, if any, will be incremented by the actual read number.

      This is a terminal method, and it is typically used to produce side effects. This method is equivalent to: 

      
 return processeTo(IOKit.nullOutputStream());
      Returns:
      the actual number of bytes read, or -1 if reaches the end of the data source and no data is read
      Throws:
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs

    • processTo

      long processTo(@Nonnull @Nonnull OutputStream dst) throws IORuntimeException
      Starts data processing, writes the processing result to the specified destination, and returns the actual number of bytes read. If reaches the end of the data source and no data is read, returns -1.

      The positions of the data source and destination, if any, will be incremented by the actual read and write numbers.

      This is a terminal method.

      Parameters:
      dst - the specified destination
      Returns:
      the actual number of bytes read, or -1 if reaches the end of the data source and no data is read
      Throws:
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs

    • processTo

      long processTo(byte @Nonnull [] dst, int off) throws IndexOutOfBoundsException, IORuntimeException
      Starts data processing, writes the processing result to the specified destination (starting at the specified offset), and returns the actual number of bytes read. If reaches the end of the data source and no data is read, returns -1.

      The positions of the data source and destination, if any, will be incremented by the actual read and write numbers.

      This is a terminal method.

      Parameters:
      dst - the specified destination
      off - the specified offset
      Returns:
      the actual number of bytes read, or -1 if reaches the end of the data source and no data is read
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the bounds arguments are out of bounds
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs

    • toByteArray

      default byte @Nonnull [] toByteArray() throws IORuntimeException
      Starts the processing, and returns the result as a new array. This method is equivalent to: 
      
     BytesBuilder builder = new BytesBuilder();
     processeTo(builder);
     return builder.toByteArray();

      The position of the data source, if any, will be incremented by the actual read number.

      This is a terminal method.

      Returns:
      the processing result as a new array
      Throws:
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs
      See Also:
      • processTo(OutputStream)

     return builder.toByteBuffer();

    • toString

      @Nonnull @Nonnull String toString() throws IORuntimeException
      Starts the processing, and returns the result as a new string with CharsKit.defaultCharset(). This method is equivalent to: 
      
     return new String(toByteArray(), CharsKit.defaultCharset());

      The position of the data source, if any, will be incremented by the actual read number.

      This is a terminal method.

      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      the processing result as a new string
      Throws:

    • toString

      @Nonnull default @Nonnull String toString(@Nonnull @Nonnull Charset charset) throws IORuntimeException
      Starts the processing, and returns the result as a new string with the specified charset. This method is equivalent to: 
      
     return new String(toByteArray(), charset);

      The position of the data source, if any, will be incremented by the actual read number.

      This is a terminal method.

      Parameters:
      charset - the specified charset
      Returns:
      the processing result as a new string
      Throws:
      IORuntimeException - if an I/O error occurs
      See Also:
      • toByteArray()

    • asInputStream

      @Nonnull @Nonnull InputStream asInputStream()
      Returns this ByteProcessor as an InputStream. The status and data source of this processor are shared with the returned InputStream, and the returned InputStream's content represents the processing result.

      The result's support is as follows:

      • mark/reset: Unsupported if any transformer(s) exist, otherwise based on the data source;
      • close: closes the data source;
      • thread safety: no;

      This is a terminal method.

      Returns:
      this ByteProcessor as an InputStream

    • asByteReader

      @Nonnull @Nonnull ByteReader asByteReader()
      Returns this ByteProcessor as a ByteReader. The status and data source of this processor are shared with the returned ByteReader, and the returned ByteReader's content represents the processing result.

      The result's support is as follows:

      • mark/reset: Unsupported if any transformer(s) exist, otherwise based on the data source;
      • close: closes the data source;
      • thread safety: no;

      This is a terminal method.

      Returns:
      this ByteProcessor as a ByteReader

    • toCharEncoder

      @Nonnull default @Nonnull CharProcessor toCharEncoder(@Nonnull @Nonnull Charset charset)
      Converts this ByteProcessor to a CharProcessor with the specified charset.

      This is a terminal method.

      Parameters:
      charset - the specified charset
      Returns:
      a new CharProcessor converted from this ByteProcessor with the specified charset
